title: Curaçao - Conflict Data
org: Armed Conflict Location & Event Data Project (ACLED)

bites.title: Map of locations
bite: Around 26 November 2020 (week of), in Willemstad, Curacao, protesters gathered in the city centre to protest against an emergency law which they claim violate constitutional rights. The law is being debated in Parliament to respond to the coronavirus. [size=no report]

On 23 November 2020, in Willemstad, Curacao, protesters gathered in the city centre to protest against an emergency law which they claim violate constitutional rights. The law is being debated in Parliament to respond to the coronavirus. [size=no report]

On 23 November 2020, in Willemstad, Curacao, around 20 people gathered in the city centre to protest against an emergency law which they claim violate constitutional rights. The law is being debated in Parliament to respond to the coronavirus. [size=around 20]
On 8 September 2020, at the coast of Curacao, the coast guard stopped a boat with 43 Venezuelan refugees and detained them.

On 3 September 2020, in Willestad, Curacao, people protested during the visit of the Dutch state secretary. The Dutch government imposed conditions for the delivery of financial support to deal with the coronavirus pandemic. Protesters claim that such conditions bring them back to colonial times. [size=no report]
On 1 September 2020, in Willemstad, Curacao, drivers including bus, taxi and truck drivers blocked a bridge in protest over rising fuel costs. [size=no report]

On 19 August 2020, in Willemstad, around 50 to 60 civil servants protested in front of the Fort Amsterdam governmental palace during a ministerial meeting. The civil servants were protesting against a decision made to categorize ministers and members of parliament in a higher salary scale. The protest took place shortly after a 12,5% salary cut for government personnel as a part of a deal to increase funds directly related to coronavirus measures. [size=around 50 to 60]
On 6 July 2020, in Willemstad, Curacao, five people protested in front of the government palace to claim their right to protest. [size=5]
On 5 July 2020, in Willemstad, teachers protested in front of the government palace against the proposed cut to salaries of government employees by 12,5%. [size=no report]
On 2 July 2020, in Willemstad, hundreds of teachers, students and parents marched in protest against budget cuts in the educational sector and to the salaries of teachers. [size=hundreds]

On 1 July 2020, in Willestad, family, friends and supporters of the main organizer of riots arrested a week earlier, gathered in support with signs outside the prison as he was released. [size=no report]

On 25 June 2020, in Willemstad, rioters demonstrated violently in the streets for a second day in a row. The government mobilized additional security forces to keep the calm in the city. There were 21 arrests made and over 120 fires were reported - both small fires of burning trash cans and stacks of tires, to bigger fires in buildings and cars. [size=no report]
Labour Group (Curacao); ABVO: General Union for Government Employees

On 24 June 2020, in Willemstad, government employees of the ABVO Union demonstrated against the announcement that their salaries could be cut because of the crisis caused by the coronavirus and were joined by other unhappy workers, marching to the governmental palace. Police used tear gas to dispserse the group, in response to which groups of rioters set a police vehicle on fire and erected burning barricades. Shops throughout the city were looted and buses burned. [size=hundreds]
On 24 June 2020, in all of Curacao, a curfew was installed after rioters looted and vandalised parts of the city center when a demonstration escalated.
On 3 June 2020, in Willemstad, Curacao, a group of people staged a Black Lives Matter protest against racism, sparked by protests in the United States. [size=no report]
Around 8 May 2020 (as reported), in Willemstad, Curacao, employees of a brothel protested with pots and pans against lack of payment of social benefits to which they are entitled. [size=no report]
On 30 March 2020, throughout Curacao a curfew was imposed to stop the spread of coronavirus.
As reported on 23 March 2020, the borders of Curacao are closed to prevent the spread of coronavirus. On 28 March 2020 the country imposed a curfew.

On 17 or 18 February 2020 in Willemstad, there was a clash between two groups of prisoners, a Venezuelan group attacked a group of Curacaoans, setting a mattress on fire, blocking access so the guards could not get in, and attacking a guard with a sharp object. The guards managed to enter and fired warning shots at the prisoners. [size=no report]
On 29 December 2019 in Punda, Willemstad, a number of protesters, many former employees, showed their discontent with the sale of the government-owned Refineria Isla. [size=no report]
Vigilante Korsou; SXM Talks; Antiliaans Dagblad
On 17 December 2019 in Willemstad, some 150 lottery employees gathered to protest the arrest of the lottery business owner, suspected of the murder of an MP. [size=150]
On November 10, 2019, in Willemstad, protesters marched against violence against women. [size=no report]
On September 27, 2019, in Willemstad, at least 1500 people participated in the Gay Pride march. [size=at least 1500]

On July 12, 2019, approximately 800 to 1000 protesters against legalizing gay marriage marched from Waaigat to Plaza Wilhelmina in Willemstad. The protest was organized by Fundashon Ban Halsa e Standarte, Asosashon Pastornan Kristian and Fundashon Proteha Famia, and several MPs are reported to have participated. [size=800]
On February 17 2019, a protest took place in Willemstad, Curacao, to protest Curacao's position on the humanitarian help provided to Venezuela. [size=no report]
On February 8 2019, teachers in Willemstad, Curacao, took the streets to protest. [size=no report]
On February 5 2019, employees of an oil refinery protested by blocking various roads and burning tires in Willemstad, Curacao. [size=no report]
On January 19 2019, residents of Curacao, protested to demand a fair trial for former prime minister Schotte. [size=no report]

On 12 December 2018, in Willemstad, Curacao, members of the FRK (Curacao Revolutionary Force) protested against a series of emergency laws claiming that these would bypass the regular legislative procedure. [size=no report]
Police Forces of Curacao (2017-) Prison Guards

Around 10 December 2018, prisoners in a prison in Willemstad, Curacao, started a riot to demonstrate against the poor conditions and lack of food in the prison. Prison guards used tear gas against the prisoners.
Police Forces of Curacao (2017-) Prison Guards
On 8 December 2018, prisoners initiated a riot in a prison in Willemstad, Curacao, to demonstrate agaisnt the poor prison conditions. Police used tear gas to halt the riot.
MFK: Movement for the Future of Curacao

On 5 December 2018, in Willemstad, Curacao, supporters of the former MFK party leader marched to the prison where he was being incarcerated after being sentenced to prison for corruption and money laundering. [size=no report]
On 22 August 2018, students of a vocational school in Willemstad, Curacao, protested against the closure of their school.

Around 20 August 2018 (as reported), in Willemstad, Curacao, students took over their school to protest its closure. The Minister of Justice came to talk to them after which they stopped the lockup of their school but continued the protest. [size=no report]

On 16 August 2018, in Willemstad, Curacao, about 150 protesters gathered at the Baoase beach resort to protest against a fence that was put up there which blocked access to the sea. Initially the protest was peaceful, but protesters then started attempting to break through the fence and stormed the resort. Police at first stood by but eventually intervened to clear the protesters from the grounds of the resort. [size=about 150]
On 8 August 2018, off the coast of Sint Wilibrordus, Curacao, the coast guard intercepted a boat with 28 Venezuelan people trying to enter Curacao and took them into custody.
On 16 May 2018, protesters gathered in Willemstad, Curacao, to protest the persecution of the security guard who shot down two people the week earlier. They believe he acted out of self-defense.
